 On his way home after his first visit to America, Sigmund Freud wrote to his wife:
 
 "Amerika ist ein Fehler: ein gigantischer Fehler!"
 
 [America is a mistake: a gigantic mistake!]
 
 Is America a mistake? Or does it have some redeeming qualities?
 
 I will begin the discussion by making the case for America being a mistake, as forcefully as I can.
 
 -

-
 
 It is a commonly held belief in many parts of the world that the 
 defects in American society stem from the fact that America was 
 originally settled by people who were genetically defective. They 
 say: look at those who first came: religious lunatics, criminals, 
 indentured servants, people so brutal that they found slavery 
 acceptable, and in general, large numbers of losers who could not 
 make it back home.
 
 There is a certain plausibility in this argument, but I think it 
 fails. In the nature-nurture debate, in general, the preponderance of 
 evidence is on the side of nurture. After all, the only thing DNA 
 codes for is the production of proteins. If a defect cannot be traced 
 back to some variation in protein production, it almost certainly is 
 not genetic in origin. No, my dear fellow Americans, our faults are 
 not in our stars, but in ourselves.
 
 Then there is the cultural determinism argument: America was set on 
 its course by the type of societies founded by the first settlers. In 
 New England these were theocracies set up by groups of religious 
 fanatics whose nearest counterpart in the modern world would be the 
 Taliban in Afghanistan. In the South, there was a brutal and indolent 
 ruling class of planters who found nothing wrong in human slavery. 
 Certainly there was serious damage to the intellect and a coarsening 
 of moral fiber among a people who for hundreds of years insisted that 
 another group of people who were obviously human beings were not, in 
 fact, human beings.
 
 Then there is the argument that civilized Europeans came to America 
 to tame the wilderness, and the wilderness turned them into savages. 
 There is, I think, some truth in this observation, but not as it is 
 usually understood. People who bring up this line of thought will say 
 that the British immigrants were under constant danger of Indian 
 attack and slave uprisings and that this constant stress goes a long 
 way toward explaining the tetchiness and incipient hysteria that has been 
 noted for centuries as a strong aspect of the American character. It 
 is also asserted that life was hard for the early settlers, and that 
 this helps to explain the brutality of the people and the coarseness 
 of their culture.
 
 Certainly there were dangers---attacks [usually self-provoked] were, 
 from time to time, made upon the settlers by the indians. But these 
 attacks, though tragic for individuals, did not, after the first few 
 decades of settlement, seriously threaten the safety and integrity of 
 the colonies. Furthermore, can one say that intermittent and minor 
 attacks by the dispossessed native population were worse than what 
 often faced Europeans on their own continent at the same period? 
 Certainly living in the path of the invading armies of Louis XIV or 
 the Duke of Marlborough was at least as stressful and dangerous as 
 anything the American colonists faced!
 
 As for the hardships and privations of life on the new continent--- 
 well, it is true that in the first wave of migration, in both New 
 England and Virginia, a considerable number of the colonists were 
 incompetent bozos who did not know what they were doing, and who 
 starved to death in the midst of plenty. However, after a sufficient 
 number of minimally sensible people had arrived in the New World, 
 life was easier, not harder, than it had been in the old country. 
 Large amounts of land were available, the soil was as yet not 
 depleted, forests were vast and game abundant. Society was still run 
 in a corporative fashion as it had been in Britain, and settlement 
 was more orderly and regulated than it was to be after the 
 Revolution. It was in those later days that hardship came to the 
 frontier as disorderly masses of people rushed out into the newly 
 opened lands in a higglety-pigglety fashion with few supplies, little 
 money, and a lack of organization.

No, I think that the damaging effects on the American character came, 
 and still come, from the abundance of life, not its privations. In a 
 state of abundance you do not need to co-operate with other people to 
 survive; you can ignore other people's feelings and opinions with 
 impunity. Also, vanity and arrogance are encouraged. It is said that 
 the problem with the self-made man is that he worships his creator. 
 Those who suffer from the illusion that they do not need the help of 
 other people in order to survive often become cocky and unbearably 
 self-important. The attitude grows: I'm all right, Jack; so screw you.
 In Germany there is a vice which is much commented upon; it is called 
 Schadenfreude, and it means taking pleasure in the misfortunes of 
 others. It is a passive vice; if someone slips and falls on a patch 
 of ice, and you smile with amusement, that is Schadenfreude. It does 
 not mean deliberately and actively setting a booby-trap for another 
 person. This second, more active, form of unamiability is a prominent 
 feature of the American character, and forms a part of that streak of 
 sociopathy and incipient hysteria which makes so many Americans so 
 unpleasant to be around. This vice has been neatly summed up by the 
 percipient Gore Vidal as: "It is not enough to succeed; others must fail."
 
 Two other important factors in the spiritual deformity of Americans 
 are the twin vices of hypocrisy and lying. Hypocrisy exists in every 
 society, though Americans seem to cultivate it with special fervor. 
 But lying is cultivated with fanatical devotion by Americans; it is 
 hypertrophied to a spectacular degree in every aspect of American 
 life. Americans lie about everything--- all the time. Morning, noon 
 and night, day after day, month after month, year after year---lies, 
 lies, lies: rivers of lies, Niagaras of lies, oceans of lies--- 
 ceaselessly pouring over the eroding psyches of the American people. 
 There are official lies, lies for reasons of state, lies to cover up 
 government malfeasance, lies for money, lies for power, lies to 
 protect those with money and power, lies in the media, lies in 
 entertainment, lies in advertising, lies in public relations, lies to 
 cover up lies, and lies to cover up those lies.
 
 Falseness is the very foundation of the modern American character.
 Lying is an obsession in these United States of Hysteria; Americans 
 cannot stop lying; they can no longer distinguish truth from 
 falsehood; and the most dangerous thing of all is that they believe 
 their own lies---they all do, from the zombies at the bottom to the 
 vampires at the top. Americans can no longer think straight, and their
 emotions are a mess.

Please look at this picture:
 
 
 The True Face of America
 
 
 Examine the picture carefully; I challenge any 
 person born in America, if there is the smallest fragment of 
 truth and honor left in his or her heart, to deny that something deep 
 and fundamental about the American psyche is revealed there. That 
 something is raw, naked hysteria; it lies very close to the surface 
 in the American character. Of course, ever since the Second World 
 War, those with money and power have been keeping the mass of 
 people---and themselves---perpetually on the verge of hysteria; it is 
 so much easier to manipulate people when they are in that condition. 
 This single fact goes a long way to explaining the sadness, stress 
 and confusion that have haunted most Americans decade after decade in 
 modern times; they are abused children who have never been allowed to 
 heal.

This evil has been carefully cultivated by the vampires who rule us, 
 but it is not new; its roots are sunk deep in the American character 
 and run back far in time. In fact, at intervals of about twenty to 
 thirty years, waves of mass hysteria have broken out in American 
 history.
 
 There was the hysteria associated with the Alien and Sedition Act at 
 the end of the 1790's. There was a revival of hysteria at the time of 
 the War of 1812, then a period of quiescence until the election of 
 that loathsome monster, Andrew Jackson. He initiated an almost 
 uninterrupted period of hysteria for more than a decade: the 
 destruction of the Bank of the United States, the ethnic cleansing 
 and genocide of the Five Nations, the anti-foreign, anti-Catholic, 
 anti-Mason hysteria of the Know-Nothing Party, and of course the 
 Manifest Destiny hysteria that led to the Mexican-American War. That 
 war, with barely a pause for breath, initiated the ever-growing 
 hysteria of the 1850's which brought on the Civil War. That war was 
 the most useless and unnecessary war of modern times; more than two 
 per-cent of the American population died because of that war---about 
 the same number and percentage that America at present is murdering

 for thirty years, slavery would have ended anyway---serfdom in Russia

 States so much more backward than Russia and Brazil that slavery 
 would have hung on until the twentieth century? All that misery and 
 death could have been avoided, and all the wounds and bitterness and 
 injustice that lasted so long. But Oh no, Americans must have their 
 hysterical fits; by the late 1850's each side had so worked itself 
 into a passion, so convinced itself that it was agrieved and wronged, 
 so filled itself with righteous indignation, self-pity and 
 intransigence that a paroxysm of gibbering, murderous rage could not 
 be avoided.
 
 Then there was the peace of exhaustion for thirty-odd years until the 
 nonsense of Free Silver and "You shall not crucify Mankind upon a 
 cross of gold" primed the pump for the phony Maine Incident and the 
 Spanish-American War. By this time the hysteria was being much more 
 consciously directed. Next was the war hysteria of the First World 
 War, the Ku Klux Klan hysteria of the early twenties, not forgetting 
 the hysteria that led to Prohibition, which made the world safe for 
 the Mafia and the FBI. Take another hop and a skip to the Second 
 World War, when hysteria made it seem perfectly acceptable to throw 
 American citizens into concentration camps, mass-murder civilians in

 Next the little palace coup of the Kennedy Assassination set the stage 
 for the prolonged hysteria of the Vietnam War [see the picture above for 
 documentary coverage]. Then there was a longer than usual period of 
 relative quiet---just constant, low-level hysteria---until Monika 
 Lewinski, 2000 election fraud, neo-con staged 9-11 attacks, and the

 hysteria. We still have the collapse of the dollar to look forward

 And when the six percent of the world's population which is represented
